work out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to think carefully about how you are going to do something and plan a good way of doing it
work out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: UN negotiators have worked out a set of compromise proposals.
I had it all worked out (=had made very careful plans).
We need to work out how we’re going to get there.
work out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to calculate an answer, amount, price etc
work out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: See if you can work this bill out.
We’ll have to work out how much food we’ll need for the party.
work out how much/how many etc
work out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to think about something and manage to understand it
work out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The plot is very complicated – it’ll take you a while to work it out.
I’m sure you can work it out for yourself.
work out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: if a cost or amount works out at a particular figure, it is found to be that much when you calculate it
work out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: The bill works out at £15 each.
If we go by taxi, it’s going to work out very expensive.
work out.translation[0].definitions[4].d: if a problem or complicated situation works out, it gradually gets better or gets solved
work out.translation[0].definitions[4].e: Things will work out, you’ll see.
I hope it all works out for Gina and Andy.
I’m sure everything will work itself out.
work out.translation[0].definitions[5].d: if a situation works out in a particular way, it happens in that way
work out.translation[0].definitions[5].e: Financially, things have worked out well for us.
work out.translation[0].definitions[6].d: to make your body fit and strong by doing exercises
work out.translation[0].definitions[6].e: He works out with weights twice a week.
work out.translation[0].definitions[7].d: used to say that you cannot understand what someone is really like or why they behave in the way they do
work out.translation[0].definitions[7].e: I couldn’t work her out at all.
work out.translation[0].definitions[8].d: if a mine is worked out, all the coal, gold etc has been removed from it
work out.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to calculate an amount, price, or value
work out.translation[1].definitions[0].e: We need to work out how much they owe us.
Can anyone work this bill out?
work out.translation[1].definitions[1].d: if something works out at a particular amount, you calculate that it costs that amount
work out.translation[1].definitions[1].e: The bill works out at £15 each.
If we employ contract workers, it’s going to work out very expensive.
work out.translation[1].definitions[2].d: to think carefully about how you are going to do something and plan a good way of doing it
work out.translation[1].definitions[2].e: The leading industrial nations have agreed to work out some arrangements for debt rescheduling.
work out.translation[1].definitions[3].d: if a mine is worked out, all the coal, gold etc has been removed from it
